{
"step_by_step_thinking": "Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) is a multisystem disease characterized by exacerbations and remissions. According to the documents, JIA can be divided into four groups: Seronegative poliarthritis, Seropositive poliarthritis, B-27 negative oligoarthritis, and B-27 positive oligoarthritis. The question asks which of the following is not a feature of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis. We need to examine each option to determine if it is related to JIA or not.

Option A: Rheumatoid nodule - This is actually a feature of adult rheumatoid arthritis, but not specifically mentioned as a feature of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Option B: Spikes of high fever - This could be related to the systemic onset patients in group I (Seronegative poliarthritis) or group II (Seropositive poliarthritis).

Option C: Uveitis - This is actually mentioned as a complication of B-27 negative oligoarthritis, which is one of the subgroups of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Option D: Raynaud's phenomenon - There is no mention of this feature in the documents related to juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Based on this analysis, we can conclude that Option D: Raynaud's phenomenon is not a feature of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.",
"answer_choice": "D"
}
